text: but the fact that the conservative grassroots rewards anti-tech bombthrowing rather than vehement pushback against thoroughly anti-free market proposals to, say, break up these large companies I think underscores my point here
author: lachlan

text: which is to say that, yes, there certainly a lot of fair-weather free marketeering on the right. But there's also less of a reflex to push back on less libertarian elements internally, meaning the ascendant Tuckeresque wing faces less pushback
author: lachlan

text: yeah this is a fair critique. My sense is that folks who would otherwise be more vocal in free market defenses of large companies are less inclined to do so when they feel those companies are inherently hostile to their ideas or their "side"
author: lachlan

text: I'm not excusing it. I think the drift away from free market principles is a feature, not a bug, of Trump-era conservatism. See Tucker's daily monologues, for instance. Libertarianism in the GOP is at a post-war low point at the moment.
author: lachlan

text: As @Surabees put it to the Daily Beast the other day, these companies are "radicalizing" folks on the right, many of whom might come around to very radical, Warren-esque measures simply because Google, FB, et al have burned all good will with otherwise free market-oriented folks.
author: lachlan

text: Hawley assuming the mantle of big tech hawk, and doing it from a conservative perspective, in very cogent terms, has been really interesting to watch

text: Meanwhile, the chief marketing officer for one of the companies told me on Tuesday that Rouda still sat on their board, and "has no plans" to leave. Then their CEO called me later that day to say that the CMO didn't have up-to-date info and that Rouda had resigned on March 8.
author: lachlan

text: This actually turned into a comedy of errors. When I reached out to Rouda's office, they said he'd resigned from all boards. Then they followed up to say he actually still sat on six of them. Then they followed up again to say he resigned from 2 in January and another 4 last week
author: lachlan

text: And finally, HR 1 contains a provision barring members of congress from serving on corporate boards. When he cosponsored the legislation, Rep. Harley Rouda still sat on four of them
author: lachlan

text: Inslee's super PAC has already spent at least $1.25M. Who do suppose is funding that? Professors and social workers? It's either coming from very wealthy individuals, likely business executives, or other political groups that aren't bound by the no-corporate-PAC-money pledge.
author: lachlan

text: Corporate *execs* are even more restricted. They can donate $2,800 per election. Unless, of course, you have a supportive super PAC. In which case they can—and do—donate millions of their own $. And unlike PAC $, which is provided by employees, this comes right from the c-suite.
author: lachlan

text: Here's why: campaigns can only accept $5k per election from PACs. So the total benefit of corporate PAC $ is small compared to individual contribs. Over their careers, Gillibrand, Booker, and Harris, for instance, have received 9%, 8%, and 2% of total contribs from corporate PACs
author: lachlan

text:

Does that make the "no corporate PAC money" pledge any less meaningless? Nope.

Fourth in the line of succession for Virginia governor is statehouse speaker Kirk Cox.

Cox is the speaker due to a one-seat GOP majority.

It has that majority because Rep. David Yancey won his seat in a coin toss.

It went to a coin toss because that race ended in a tie.

Vote!

Vendors for Warren's exploratory committee did $500k+ in work by the time she officially launched on 12/31.

But actually paying the vendors would've required setting up the committee, giving away her plans.

author: lachlan

text: Incidentally, you're also seeing federal PACs do more and more of this as well, classifying their fundraising efforts (direct mail, telemarketing, etc) as "independent expenditures" so it appears all the money they're spending on fundraising is actually being spent on politics.
author: lachlan

text: Anyway, that's just one small, specific example of the types of accounting games that these groups play in the hopes that no one notices they exist solely to dupe well-meaning donors into underwriting an incestuous, tax-exempt fundraising apparatus.
author: lachlan

text: But counting it thusly would change that crucial ratio. Taking that $850k into account, the group actually spent more than $2.2M on fundraising and about $550k on program expenses (assuming no other accounting chicanery). So the ratio is actually 75-25, not 50-50.
author: lachlan

text: At the end of the filing, there's this note: ACS actually counts $850k paid to its fundraisers as a program service "public awareness campaign," b/c fundraisers are promoting their mission to potential donors. Laughable. By any legit metric, these are simply fundraising expenses.
author: lachlan

text:
Nonprofit IRS filings require groups say how much they spent on fundraising, alongside how much they spend on "program expenses," or actual nonprofit work.

Here's ACS's 2016 filing. $1.37M on fundraising and $1.4M on program expenses. 50-50 isn't great. Many are worse. BUT...
author: lachlan

text:
Like this one, American Children's Society, which last year paid a firm owned by Richard Zeitlin, the guy under investigation, more than $550k to raise the group less than $100k

Here's how orgs like this try to hide the fact that virtually all they do is pay their fundraisers
author: lachlan

text:
So last week I wrote about a network of scam PACs and their vendors, one of whom was under federal grand jury investigation as of at least late last year https://www.thedailybeast.com/federal-grand-jury-probed-scam-pac-fundraiser …

Lots of folks involved in this scheme also run, or are paid by, similarly named sham nonprofits...
author: lachlan

text: The flip side of this of course is that Republicans *would* be calling for resignations if this conduct occurred in a D administration. And that's my whole point about ethics oversight. It happens mostly due to partisanship, which is better than it not happening at all
